Hey I am glad that you like that stuff, it was around in my computer 
a who=
le week but I decided to upload a binary just before a day. Let 
me explain=
 the details behind it. As you are probably familiar with 
the other NEVH s=
hit this code does the same but uses another NEAT 
implememtation and novel=
ty search. (steady state evolution). 
I've seen some dolls actually walking=
, but backwards. Kind of weird. 
I guess it is the easier way, though :) 
T=
he behavior characterization is (as Peter B proposed) the final XYZ 
locati=
on of the head. The distance is simply the eucldian distance 
between those=
 points. I agree that there are many options and I am 
trying out many diff=
erent BCs (behavior characterizations). But this 
one works well. 
The node=
s in the substrate are arranged in a geometric way to reflect 
the body's g=
eometry in space. Each output corresponds to a joint 
angle. Arms and legs =
are placed symmetrically in the left and right 
sides. The head (neck joint=
) is placed above them in the center. 
Outputs are drawn in green. Inputs (=
head velocity) are drawn in red. 
Hidden nodes are drawn in yellow. Ergh I =
see it is upside-down but 
HyperNEAT doesn't care about this anyway :) 
The=
 5th input to the CPPN is the distance from 0, 0 in node-specific 
data and=
 the distance between the 2 points when computing the weight 
of the connec=
tion between 2 nodes. Just like in your paper, the same 
bias. 

Peter

---=
 In neat@yahoogroups.com, "David D'Ambrosio" <ddambro84@...> wrote:
>
> Wow=
, this looks really cool Petar.  I thought it would be awhile
> before we s=
aw HyperNEAT and novelty search combined.  I ran it 
while I
> was working =
on other stuff for a bit over 50,000 evaluations, 
checking
> in on it peri=
odically.  The behavioral diversity was really
> impressive: I got guys tha=
t were taking baby steps and guys that 
were
> doing yoga poses (I swear on=
e of them did "the chair"), although 
there
> were still a good number of r=
epeats, especially near the end 
(falling
> onto theirs knees seemed pretty=
 common).  No one that I saw had a 
good
> walking gait, but I guess it's p=
ossible that one could have when I
> wasn't watching, perhaps we need an op=
tion to browse the archive. 
I'm
> curious about a few things, if you would=
n't mind sharing:
> 
> -What did you use as a novelty metric?  It's seems l=
ike there are a
> number of viable options here.
> 
> -What do the nodes on=
 the substrate mean, and are they just on a 
flat
> plane?  I used your old=
er version when it was first released, and 
if I
> remember right the two o=
n the left are inputs and the stuff on the
> right is various joints, but I=
 wanted to make sure.
> 
> -Similarly, what do you use as the 5th input on =
the CPPN?
> 
> Thanks,
> David D'Ambrosio
